item.title: Jubilant Sykes, Celebrated Opera Singer, Is Stabbed to Death
item.description: After the police found the Grammy-nominated performer in his home with fatal wounds, his son was taken into custody, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jubilant Sykes performing as the Celebrant in “Mass,” by Leonard Bernstein, at Carnegie Hall in 2008.

item.title: Best Classical Performances of 2025
item.description: Thinking outside the canon, and finding the gritty and the beautiful, within it.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone and Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: Nadine Sierra in the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “La Sonnambula,” directed by Rolando Villazón.

item.title: Timbaland’s Latest Protégée Is an A.I. Pop Singer
item.description: The producer dreamed up TaTa Taktumi and brought her to life with help from the software Suno. She’s arriving at a fraught moment for artificial intelligence in music.
item.dc:creator: David Peisner
item.media:credit: Jessica Johnson
item.media:description: Timbaland calls TaTa Taktumi, the new pop star he is developing, a “hybrid” of work done by humans and artificial intelligence. (The person pictured here is indeed real.)

item.title: Best Songs of 2025
item.description: Listen to 48 tracks that broke new artists, blew apart genres and revived beloved sounds.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica and Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: My 5 Favorite Film Scores of 2025
item.description: Nine Inch Nails’ music for “Tron: Ares,” Nala Sinephro’s compositions for “The Smashing Machine” and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails

item.title: Raul Malo, Frontman of Latin-Tinged Country Band Mavericks, Dies at 60
item.description: As the group’s singer and principal songwriter, he brought a new sound that broadened the boundaries of country music in the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.media:credit: Rich Fury/Getty Images for Stagecoach
item.media:description: Raul Malo performing in 2022. Sticking to tradition and one genre, he said, “just wasn’t for me.”

item.title: Review: Two New Bach Pieces? The Real Thrill Was in the Chase.
item.description: Two workmanlike pieces by the teenage Bach had their New York premiere at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.
item.dc:creator: Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
item.category: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center

item.title: Christine Baranski and ‘A Christmas Carol’: A Natural Pairing
item.description: On a recent recording, and in concerts this month, Baranski reads Dickens’s holiday classic with the Skylark Vocal Ensemble.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: Ye Fan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christine Baranski reading from Charles Dickens’s manuscript for “A Christmas Carol” at the Morgan Library and Museum.

item.title: Katy Perry Posts Photos With Justin Trudeau Amid Romance Rumors
item.description: Ms. Perry and Mr. Trudeau, the former prime minister of Canada, posed together in photos and videos on Instagram, making them “Instagram official.”
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Jordan Strauss/Invision, via Associated Press, Miguel a Lopes, via EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: From Improv Class to Mayor-Elect: Zohran Mamdani’s Cultural Influences
item.description: In an interview, he revealed the Indian ragas, indie movies, comedy shows and museums in the city that stayed with him.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
item.media:description: In some ways, Zohran Mamdani’s cultural influences would be familiar to any New York City kid.

item.title: Frank Gehry’s Buildings Sound as Marvelous as They Look
item.description: Gehry, who died on Friday at 96, made an invaluable contribution to classical music by designing spaces with stunning acoustics.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.category: Fisher, Richard B, Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College
item.media:credit: View Pictures/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The swooping interior of Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles.

item.title: Danny Brown Is Proud of His New Beats and Gym Physique
item.description: The rapper chats about the experimental pop collaborators and healthy habits that fueled his sixth album, “Stardust.”
item.dc:creator: Ross Scarano
item.media:credit: Jason Bollenbacher/SXSW Conference & Festivals, via Getty Images

item.title: Bublé for a Day, but He Can’t Sing and There’s Little Resemblance
item.description: Dan Perlman, a comedian, looks and sounds nothing like Michael Bublé. And yet, for some reason, he was hired to impersonate the crooner at a birthday party.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: Dan Perlman, a writer and comedian, was game, if bemused, when he was drafted to appear as the singer Michael Bublé at a stranger’s 60th birthday party.

item.title: The Pittsburgh Symphony Plays How an Orchestra Should Sound
item.description: Under its music director, Manfred Honeck, the ensemble returned to Carnegie Hall for the first time in over a decade, flying in on a high.
item.dc:creator: David Allen
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Manfred Honeck, the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra’s music director, who holds the ensemble to stratospherically high standards.

item.title: Best Albums of 2025
item.description: The Korean pop outsider Effie and the Brooklyn indie-rock band Geese top our critics’ lists this year.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica and Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Kevin Mazur/Getty Images

item.title: Best Jazz Albums of 2025
item.description: The most compelling releases of the year reimagined hip-hop tracks, deep-rooted collaborations and longstanding inspirations.
item.dc:creator: Hank Shteamer

item.title: Steve Cropper: 9 Essential Songs
item.description: An architect of Memphis soul, Cropper made his guitar sing and sting. And as a songwriter, he collaborated on more than a few indelible anthems.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles
item.media:credit: Don Paulsen/Michael Ochs Archives, via Getty Images

item.title: Eurovision Is in Turmoil as Israel’s Participation Leads to Boycott
item.description: The Netherlands and Slovenia also said they would not take part in next year’s contest, meant to be its celebratory 70th edition.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Denis Balibouse/Reuters
item.media:description: Yuval Raphael, Israel’s 2025 Eurovision act, performing in May. The country has won the contest four times.

item.title: Larry Mitchell and Ned Asta’s Queer Cult Classic Debuts in New York
item.description: “The Faggots and Their Friends Between Revolutions” is a music theater piece based on Larry Mitchell and Ned Asta’s 1970s book.
item.dc:creator: Juan A. Ramírez
item.category: The Faggots and Their Friends Between Revolutions (Book)
item.media:credit: Rachel Papo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The story’s loose narrative follows a group of marginalized people whose communal living clashes against the powerful capitalist patriarchy.

item.title: In Ephrat Asherie’s ‘Shadow Cities,’ Club Dance Meets Latin Jazz
item.description: Ephrat Asherie’s “Shadow Cities” pairs her group’s adept dancers with live music by the great Arturo O’Farrill.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ephrat Asherie, left, and dancers in “Shadow Cities” at the Joyce Theater.

item.title: Steve Cropper, Guitarist, Songwriter and Shaper of Memphis Soul Music, Dies at 84
item.description: As a member of Booker T. & the MG’s and as a producer, he played a pivotal role in the rise of Stax Records, a storied force in R&B in the 1960s and ’70s.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.category: (Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay (Song)
item.media:credit: David Reed Archive/Alamy
item.media:description: Steve Cropper in 1973. His guitar licks could be heard in hits by Otis Redding, Sam & Dave and Wilson Pickett, among many others.

item.title: Spotify Wrapped Has Users Talking About Their ‘Listening Age’
item.description: The wrinkle in this year’s Spotify Wrapped release was an estimate of the user’s “listening age.” Some wore it like a badge of honor. Others made excuses.
item.dc:creator: Madison Malone Kircher

item.title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love the A.A.C.M.
item.description: The Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians in Chicago has built community and pushed musical boundaries for 60 years. Hear 13 tracks from this jazz institution.
item.dc:creator: Marcus J. Moore
item.category: Assn for the Advancement of Creative Musicians

item.title: Paul Williams, Songwriter for the Muppets and the Carpenters, Takes a Bow
item.description: Paul Williams is known for his ability to elicit both laughter and tears. This week, he and his decades of music will be celebrated at the 92nd Street Y.
item.dc:creator: Elysa Gardner
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: “I never had a treehouse when I was a kid, a place where you’d be up hanging with your gang,” Williams said. “As soon as I walked on the set and met the Muppets and Jim, I had a treehouse.”

item.title: Sondheim’s ‘Merrily We Roll Along’ Is Now a Film. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: The Broadway revival, starring Daniel Radcliffe, Jonathan Groff and Lindsay Mendez, was transformative. Here’s what to know about the show, and the movie.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jonathan Groff, with Daniel Radcliffe and other cast members, at the “Merrily We Roll Along” taping in 2024.

item.title: American Sports Are Turning Up the Volume of Afrobeats
item.description: With an eye on its international fan base, the N.B.A. has welcomed the influence of African singers like Tems, Burna Boy and Rema.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Alex Goodlett/Getty Images
item.media:description: Burna Boy performing at halftime of the N.B.A. All-Star Game in 2023. This year his hit single “Don’t Let Me Drown” was featured on the soundtrack of “F1: The Movie.”
